config.question: Why was Whig candidate Winfield Scott so easily defeated in the presidential campaign of 1852?

choices.content: He allied himself with the northern antislavery wing of the Whig party.
He supported nativist Whigs and promised to restrict immigrant voting rights.
He advocated a program of limited government involvement in business.
Most immigrants from Europe were Catholics, and the Whig following was largely evangelical Protestant.

answer_3.response: The main cause for Scott’s crushing defeat in the presidential campaign of 1852 was the support he lost in the South when he allied himself with the northern antislavery wing of the party, led by Senator William Seward of New York.
